title: 113_hr1929
content: The Act is titled the "Enhancing Employment and Training Through Education Act of 2013." It includes pilot projects to reduce dependency and increase work effort in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. Section 17 of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include pilot projects aimed at increasing work effort and reducing dependency in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. The projects will focus on identifying best practices for employment and training programs to help participants secure unsubsidized employment, increase earned income, and decrease reliance on public assistance. Selection criteria for the pilot projects will be based on established guidelines. The pilot projects under the amended Section 17 of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 aim to enhance employment and training programs, participate in evaluations, collaborate with workforce boards, ensure replicability, and target various populations. The pilot projects under the amended Section 17 of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 target a variety of work registrants, including childless adults, parents, and individuals with low skills or limited work experience. These projects are selected from existing employment and training programs, such as section 20 workfare, skills development, post-employment support services, and education leading to employment. The pilot projects under the amended Section 17 of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 target a variety of work registrants, including childless adults, parents, and individuals with low skills or limited work experience. These projects aim to provide education leading to a recognized postsecondary credential, registered apprenticeship, or secondary school diploma. The evaluation will measure the impact on finding and retaining employment leading to increased household income. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress by September 30, 2017, detailing the results of each pilot project, including the impact on employment, income, and public benefit receipt of work registrants. The report will also cover the costs of each project and the planned dissemination of findings with State agencies. The Secretary will report to Congress by September 30, 2017, on the results of pilot projects, including their impact on employment and income. $10,000,000 will be available annually from 2014 to 2016 for pilot projects that comply with the Act. These funds will cover project costs and administration. The funds available for pilot projects will cover project costs, data provision, and evaluation expenses. These funds cannot replace non-Federal funds for existing employment and training activities.
